message:
Offline backup solution,
Any advice about a backup solution for PCs running windows OS , I need a third party software.
*I don't need the built in windows backup tool.
Any suggestions ?

data.message: have you searched on google before posting your question ?
yup and didn't know what to go with, that's why I'm asking here :)

Well here is an answer that might not be on the first page of google search...
I personally use a unknown tool called SyncToy made by Microsoft, you can easily configure it to either sync between two drives or mirror the changes (if you delete from the source it gets deleted from the target).
I like it because it's a very simple tool and very straight forward.
You can get it from here: http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=15155

Edit: notice that this is not a complete backup solution, it wont automatically backup a whole partition and restore it, this is more suitable for backing up just your important folders
if you want program to take backup from window partitions you can use program like Acronis or norton ghost , I don't know if you mean something like this or not

و هنا في حاجات تانية http://lifehacker.com/5498381/five-best-offline-backup-tools

rsync دا كويس برضه بستخدمه في لينكس
I'm curious, is the built in backup tool for windows that bad? A lot of people seem to avoid it.
Hassan Aly Selim Many thanks, this tool can be useful and I can use it in some particular situations.

Sakura Rosace honestly I want a program to backup the entire OS including user data. I will look up for Acronis because I don't know it and compare it with Ghost and other alternatives. Thanks bro for your contribution.
Mostafa Hussein  Thanks, I will take a look at these collection, and if anyone fits my needs I will go with it.
Omar Majed I suppose what you're looking for is a disk clone, http://lifehacker.com/5839753/the-best-disk-cloning-app-for-windows

Hady Ahmed Honestly windows 7 backup tool looks good but because we have both XP and 7 I can't go with it. I think it's not available on XP or XP version is poor, that's why I'm looking for one software which can manage this issue across XP and 7.

I personally don't think that backing up the whole OS is a good idea, I just backup the stuff I want, and I also backup the AppData folder so that when I make a fresh install I can easily restore my settings and configurations, and I also try to get portable (or zip) releases of programs instead of installers when available, so in the end the OS itself doesn't matter much to me.

Edit: I'm assuming personal use here
Hady Ahmed Thanks Bro, I think that one sounds great because it can be run from a live cd in case system is down plus schedule automatic backups. I would try it.

I suppose it's a matter of personal preference, for a *nix system that's about the easiest backup policy to go for. Personally, I do a deep clone minus logs and crash dumps which usually shaves off several gigs, getting a complete restore back to the original state has been indispensable for my work. It's also lazy and storage is cheap, a win all-around.

Hassan Aly Selim I agree with you but because there are lot of computers in the company around 35 to 45 PCs so I would get rid of formatting and fresh windows copy installation process especially there is a specialized ticketing system software that needs to be activated from the providing company at each installation so a full backup can help bypass that.
